==English==

===Etymology===
From {{etyl|enm}} {{term|weke|lang=enm}}, from {{etyl|ang}} {{term|wice|lang=ang}}, {{term|wucu||week|lang=ang}}, from {{proto|Germanic|wikÅn|turn, succession, change, week|lang=en}}, from {{proto|Indo-European|weig-||weik-|to bend, wind, turn, yield|lang=en}}. Related to {{proto|Germanic|wÄ«kanan|to bend, yield, cease|lang=en}}.{{attention|nl|The following should be duplicated beneath==Dutch==I assume.}} The Dutch noun derives from a related verb {{recons|waikwaz||to yield}}, via the current Dutch form {{term|wijken|lang=nl||to cede, give way}}.

Related words are Old High German {{term|wohha|lang=goh}} (Modern German {{term|Woche|lang=de}}), Old Frisian {{term|wike|lang=ofs}}, Middle Dutch {{term|weke||week|lang=dum}}, Old Saxon {{term|wika|lang=osx}}, Old Norse {{term|vika|lang=non}}, Gothic {{term|ğ…ğŒ¹ğŒºğ‰|sc=Goth|tr=wikÃ´||turn for temple service|lang=got}}, Old English {{term|wican|wÄ«can|lang=ang||to yield, give way}}.

===Pronunciation===
* {{enPR|wÄ“k}}, {{IPA|/wiËk/}}, {{X-SAMPA|/wi:k/}}
* {{audio|en-us-week.ogg|Audio (US)}}
* {{audio|En-uk-a week.ogg|Audio (UK)|lang=en}}
* {{rhymes|iËk}}
* {{homophones|weak|lang=en}}

===Noun===
{{wikipedia}}
{{en-noun}}

# Any [[period]] of [[seven]] consecutive [[day]]s.
# A period of seven days beginning with [[Sunday]] or [[Monday]].
# A subdivision of the [[month]] into longer periods of work days punctuated by shorter [[weekend]] periods of days for markets, rest, or religious observation such as a [[sabbath]].{{rfex}}
# Seven days after ({{n-g|sometimes}} before) a specified date.
#: I'll see you Thursday '''week'''.

====Derived terms====
{{rel-top3|Terms derived from ''week''}}
* [[bush week]]
* [[for weeks on end]]
{{rel-mid3}}
* [[hell week]]
* [[Holy Week]]
{{rel-mid3}}
* [[weekend]]
* [[weekly]]
{{rel-bottom}}

===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|/Ê‹eËk/|/weËk/|lang=nl}}

===Etymology===
From {{etyl|odt|nl}} {{recons|wika|lang=odt}}, from {{proto|Germanic|wikÅn|lang=nl}}.

====Noun====
{{nl-noun|c|weken|weekje}}

# {{l|en|week}}
